document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Defence Training Support Manual 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition Version: 1.0 Contents How to use this Manual Defence Training Support Manuals (DTSM) have been developed to support the understanding and implementation of the policy contained in JSP 822.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: JSP 822 is the authoritative policy that directs and guides Defence people to ensure that Defence Learning (training and education) is appropriate, efficient, effective and, most importantly, safe.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Using the DTSMs is entirely optional, and users may find there are alternative resources available to help them understand and implement the policy contained in JSP 822.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Throughout this document there are references to other DTSMs, these references contains hyperlinks that will take you to the DTSMs that are held on the   SharePoint site.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: This Section of the Guidance outlines the Defence approach that allows training specialists to adopt a structured, methodical approach to the analysis of the training need, or requirement.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: It sets out the various activities, collectively termed the TNA, which may be used in order to conduct a TNA, which informs subsequent Elements and forms part of the overall Training System.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Overview of the TNA A TNA is a structured analysis of training need arising as a result of new equipment acquisition, doctrinal change, organisational change, or changes to policy/legislation.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: It generally includes an analysis of different training Methods and technologies, with a view to recommending the optimum training solution which balances cost and quality.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: In all cases, however, a TNA is an output based, iterative process that provides an audit trail for all decisions and is closely mapped to the requirements of the QMS.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: If training is not the solution, this will become apparent in the Scoping Exercise, after which, analysis activity will cease.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The TNA provides an audit trail of analysis to determine the need for training and, if required, enable design of a training solution.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: However, it should be emphasised that this recommended approach is not necessarily linear nor does it have to be followed prescriptively.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: In many cases there may not be a requirement to produce all of the suggested output products, and there may be merit in conducting stages or activities concurrently.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: This identifies the Role(s) that need to be trained for, the supporting duties, tasks, sub-tasks and task-elements, then analyses these to generate Performances, Conditions and Standards.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: This is an initial draft of the TOs, based upon the Role PS and/or Framework(s), which are the key outputs.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: It may be that the initial TOs created at this stage are sufficient and do not need further refinement but they are certainly not endorsed at this stage.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The TOA considers each relevant Task in the Role PS / Competence Framework to assess the extent to which the training environment should replicate the workplace (real) environment to enable training to be effective.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The key outputs are the realistic options for Methods & Media and refinement (based upon fidelity, locations and environment) of the possible training solutions.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The Training Needs Report analyses the cost benefits and then evaluates the merits of the training options, before confirming the TNASG endorsed training solution.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: This assesses and reports on the effectiveness of the TNA process as well as the ability of the implemented training solution to meet the Defence requirement.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The key output is an assessment of how well the TNA outputs contributed to the provision of a training solution that meets the Defence requirement.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Why or when should a TNA be conducted? Before a TNA can begin, a clear evidence-based Statement of Requirement (SoR) is to be produced, preferably in a written format (letter, e-mail, request form or tasking order, for example).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Then, prior to the commencement of the analysis, a scoping exercise is conducted which may identify that the most cost-effective means of achieving the required Defence need, is a training solution2.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Once the requirement for training has been established, a TNA should be undertaken to ascertain the type and scope of the training requirement that meets the Defence need.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: It is expected that the Training Requirements Authority (TRA) will take the lead on the production of the DSAT activities, processes and outputs required to be completed during Element 1.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The TRA will also be expected to ensure that those activities deemed critical to the development of the Training System are conducted.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: A key activity is the establishment of a TNA Steering Group (TNASG), upon receipt of a SOR, or other authority, to begin the TNA process.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Considerations with a TNA Training activities should meet Defence outputs; and, should these change, the training need should be re-analysed, via a TNA, and if necessary, adapted to support the new requirement(s).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: If a TNA is to be conducted, the user should consider: the requirement being raised and the need to carry out a TNA.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: There may be different reasons for undertaking a TNA: In support of a new fielded force or training equipment or service.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: As a general rule, a TNA should be used when a change in Defence capability is likely to have a significant impact on the training resources required to generate trained output.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The TNA may vary in complexity from a simple scoping exercise to an extensive process requiring a dedicated team of Needs Analysts.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: At the start of a TNA, time is often well spent in educating those who are to be involved in the TNA about the process.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Whilst it is not usually the TNA author’s responsibility to the implement the training solution, post TNA, it is possible that they may be involved in subsequent working groups, to provide training support advice.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The need to design training from scratch on a ‘blank sheet of paper’ is a very unusual occurrence, as it is much more likely that existing training can be modified.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Where current role information, Role PS / Framework(s) or TOs do not exist for any current training, more comprehensive RA may be required, before any determination of a training requirement can be made.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: A TNA should generate a clear audit trail which plots the sequence of events and decisions leading to a training solution.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The justification and supporting evidence used as the basis for these decisions should be readily apparent (such as: references to, and/or copies of, academic research literature; the deliberations of the Analysts; minutes of TNASG meetings and Defence/Contractor publications).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: A quality audit trail requires full disclosure of, and rationale for, the methodology, tools and data sources used in the analysis, with copies of any specialist or bespoke software made available to the TNASG.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Whilst a TNA is carried out by completing a number of activities in sequence, it is important to note that the process is iterative in nature.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: It is therefore important that at every stage of a TNA, the key outputs are reviewed to ensure their continuing validity, and that stages of the process be repeated if necessary.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Follow-on changes to the training requirement and the impact on training may be managed through a system of configuration control but this does not remove the responsibility of the TNASG for ensuring that changes are reflected in the TNA.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: It should be noted that the cheapest option is not necessarily the most cost-effective option in meeting the training requirement.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Therefore, ‘effectiveness’ is the key as it is the extent to which the training has prepared the individual for the Defence effect which matters.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Cost is ‘efficiency’ focused to optimise the use of resources to enable the execution of training (and required learning) and ensure Value for Money (VfM).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: TNA Governance Introduction The name TNA Steering Group (TNASG) is commonly used for this this governance group; however, it may be known by alternative names example: Training Steering Group (TSG).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Although TNA SG is used within JSP 822 and the DTSMs, personnel should consult local policy documents to see if a preferred, alternative name is in use.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: For most training, the Chair of the TNA SG will normally be filled by the TRA, however, under certain scenarios e.g.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The complexity and size of the training requirement will dictate the level of involvement of the TRA and whether responsibilities are delegated.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Training policy and training support representatives from the TRA should direct the TNA Scoping Exercise and the TRA will normally nominate the chair of the TNASG.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Where the training need is derived from new equipment or a service being brought into service by DE&S, representation from the Project Teams, or equivalent, is key to ensuring that the training requirement meets the technical needs of the new capability.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The TDA will need to be represented at the TNASG as it is responsible for the design stages of the DSAT process and will likely be closely tied to the Training Provider.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: It is not vital for the Training Provider to be represented at the early stages of TNA, unless a specific Training Provider is obvious from the outset.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The Formation Command therefore should be represented as it will be integral to achieving the balance of training between that delivered by the Training Provider and the remainder by the Formation Command in the workplace.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The identification of appointments/posts/billets affected by a new Defence capability, as well as training throughput to resource it, are key aspects of the scoping exercise and RA.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The involvement of the relevant Workforce Authority is therefore critical to the validity of the TNA and important in ensuring that the issues that overlap between personnel/workforce and training are fully integrated and understood by all parties from the outset.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: If necessary, a training management SME should be represented in order to advise the chair on TNA management and methodology, ensure that the TNASG is representative of all stakeholders, compliant with the DSAT process, and that an audit trail exists.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: It should therefore perform the following tasks, which should form the basis for its ToRs: develop and maintain a TSP.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: TNA governance is often complicated as individuals who act as stakeholders often double as the steering/working group representatives and are therefore closely involved in the development of the TNA.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: SMEs may have pre-conceptions regarding the operation/use of different Methods & Media (SMEs may not be training professionals and may not be fully aware of the options available); so the user should be aware of the potential to influence their decisions or statements.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The TSP should identify any constraints on the TNA in terms of training policy or funding, ensuring that all the actions required to produce cost-effective training support are identified and the appropriate agencies tasked.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The TSP should also specify when the TNA activities are to be conducted, who is responsible for the management and conduct of the TNA process and when and how the outputs are to be assured.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: A RFTD should be considered at this stage, agreed and stated later as a ‘hard stop’ point, as part of the Training Authority Document (TrAD), which is produced at the end of Element 2 (Design).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Figure 1: Training Support Plan (TSP) in the TNA Context 5 RFTD is defined as the point at which all the necessary resources required to conduct training have been accepted by the TRA.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Scoping Exercise Introduction The scoping exercise involves the initial analysis of the requirement and, where applicable, suggested options for meeting the requirement including a broad order estimate of the resource implications associated with each option.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The scoping exercise should be completed as early as possible and starts by acquiring as much relevant information as possible about the training need and the Customer requirement.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: It will advise the TNA strategy for the proposed training solution and provide the parameters of the new or changed Defence requirement where TNAs will be, or have been, carried out.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The scoping exercise does not have to be a long and protracted document and can utilise electronic references such as minutes of meetings, records of conversations to provide an auditable trail.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Provided that a training need is confirmed then a search of existing training activities across Defence, including the DLE, is to be conducted to ascertain if training, already designed, could satisfy, or partly satisfy, the need.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The scoping exercise should then outline the aim, constraint, assumptions, proposed methodology and timescales, and provide an estimate of the resources required for the subsequent analysis and design stages.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The scoping exercise is the initial investigation and should derive a strategy and tentative solution for meeting the need for a training intervention.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: For example, is it necessary to complete a full Role Analysis (RA) from first principles, or is it sufficient to confirm that an existing Role PS / Framework is still valid? Likewise, the strategy may recommend the process focuses on certain elements of a Role/task Performance which need further development or perhaps recommends targeting the TOs to ensure they support a Role PS and/or Framework.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: It may be decided that the sequence of training be reviewed if this is highlighted as a potential problem or that further consideration is given to current refresher training intervals.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The scoping exercise should also cover a list of the resources required to complete the subsequent activities and an agreement as to which organisation(s) will provide them.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: A considerable amount of resources may be required to carry out these analyses and these should be made explicit within the ToRs.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Although the layout of ToRs may be adjusted to meet specific circumstances there are a number of key areas that should be considered: the scope and size of the TNA.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: TNA Plan In order to estimate the timescales for the TNA it may be necessary to generate a plan, for inclusion with the ToRs.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: It need not be detailed but as a minimum it should include what is to be done, by whom and when.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Training Audience (and Throughput) Description An estimate of who will be affected by the new or changed Defence requirement is required to ensure that it is representative and to determine throughput and input standards.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: It should include an estimate of the population to be trained in terms of their personal characteristics, the annual throughput and the input standard6.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: In the course of analysing a particular role, it is often the case that to carry out the role effectively, an individual should possess certain characteristics.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: If this is so, then it is important to determine an appropriate balance between selection and training in order to provide people who have these characteristics and who are, therefore, capable of doing the role.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The purpose of this description is to identify the: training audience groupings, the number and type of groups that need to be addressed (e.g.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Analysts should consider potential members of the training audience from across the training continuum, from individual through team to collective.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Users should identify all individuals who require training, and possibly at what stages in the training continuum they will be required to be trained.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: If possible, analysts should also identify the relevant individual career training pipelines and identify the optimal stage for any new training to be delivered.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Users should identify the appropriate rank and branch/specialisation of all individuals requiring training; and consider individuals who could require training from across all Defence Lines of Development (DLoDs), and not limit thinking to a single area.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: A team is a sub-division of an individual unit’s 6 The Defence Human Factors Integration Policy for Defence Systems (JSP 912) also requires the development of a Target Audience Description so there is the potential for re-use of information here.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Users should identify the individuals who will constitute the teams/sub-teams so that the capacity and size of any potential team training solution can be determined.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Social and demographic characteristics of the training audience provide an early training analysis that assists in determining appropriate and cost-effective training solutions.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The type and scope of information required for each training audience should be determined by the complexity of the performance requirement and the size and complexity of the training audience.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: nursing or policing require people who have a desire to do this sort of work if they are to be successful at it.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Such as willingness or motivation to attend training or career implications and career cycles as they relate to the training.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Information needs to be collected on (or assumptions made about) the role-related competences (KSAs) in which the training audience is already proficient.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The training audience’s level of KSA with respect to the Performance requirements is a factor, which depends mainly on previous related training, experience and recruitment profiles.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: When identifying the training audience, analysts should also establish whether individuals will be required to have any existing competences or experience levels prior to exploiting the new capability (pre-requisite analysis).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Some of these competences may also be required by trainer/training support staff to enable them to assess performance and develop training activities.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Example criteria include: establishing whether or not an individual’s existing competences are sufficient for them to safely operate or maintain the new capability.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: establishing the minimum level of experience required (such as, number of flying hours, previous command experience, specific operational experience etc).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Pre-requisites analysis can be used to inform the training solution recommendations and is an important measure of competence/entry standard prior to training.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: This enables more accurate measures of competence ‘before and after’ training to be taken, thereby facilitating measures of effectiveness of the training solution in delivering the required output standards.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: An estimate of training throughput numbers (total audience and annual throughput requirements) will inform requirements for the size and capacity of the potential training solution and must be made available to inform the SOTR process.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Throughput numbers may be required in support of a variety of related training solutions for each distinct training audience group.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Throughput figures should be calculated separately for each type of training required and for all affected Defence people, MoD civilians and Contractors.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Training throughput figures for all training audiences can then be used as separate requirements to be considered by users in generating potential training solutions.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: per cent posted to similar role in a different location (such as, will not need to be retrained to assume role responsibilities).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: promotion cycle and its potential impact on training numbers (such as, number of target audience who will be promoted during their assignment).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Constraints Analysis Any constraints affecting the TNA need to be analysed and highlighted to ensure that risks regarding financial, safety and technical issues are addressed.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The TNA process should initially focus on satisfying the strategic need with the caveat that proposed training solutions are compared with the initial constraints as part of the TOA and/or EA.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: the Concept of Employment for a capability) or can be determined through contextual analysis (such as via PESTLE7 or other frameworks).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The TNA should adhere to the DTEL Rules9 and Defence Policy for Modelling & Simulation (M&S) (), as well as taking account of policies on the use of the  10 and Human Factors Integration for Defence Systems ().

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Restrictions may be placed on the TNA by affordability considerations, which may restrict the number or scope of training options but could also take into account Value for Money (VfM) through-life (e.g.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: 10 See made in training and, for economic reasons11, it is advisable to build upon existing capability rather than acquire new systems).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Analysis is invariably conducted under time pressures, including the need to meet deadlines such as Initial or Full Operating Capability (I/FOC).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Therefore, the TNA should consider any prioritisation that needs to be taken account of and then constrain the analysis accordingly.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Training environments can be constrained by safety considerations, such as on the use of live fire or requirements imposed by safety cases.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Note that, regardless of training solution, there is likely to be a requirement to conduct operating assurance through the use of live equipment.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: There may be restrictions on training due to legal requirements, such as mandated hours for aircraft control duties or flying, as well as Care and Welfare responsibilities.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Given the significant impact these constraints may have, the TNA should commence with their identification and risk management13, noting the potential impact and options for mitigating any threats or the consequences of constraints.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: From this analysis, a constraints table, risk register and an assumptions register (including a Master Data Assumptions List as required) should be compiled and maintained by the analyst and reviewed by the TNASG, noting that a constraints analysis is an iterative process and may determine that a training intervention is not the most appropriate way to address the Defence need.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The Scoping Exercise Report The scoping exercise report is an output of the Scoping Exercise, detailing what is appropriate to the training need and, importantly, make training solution recommendations.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: confirmation (or otherwise) that there is a training requirement that will fulfil the SOR (if there is not, the DSAT process should then cease).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Where a training solution is recommended and agreed at the TNASG, a plan for subsequent analysis and design activities should be produced.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The problem may not have anything to do with training and may require: a revision of procedures and/or improvements to management and supervision.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: A summary description should outline the proposed capability or technology/equipment and the benefits of the new or changed training requirement in the context of the Defence effect.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Influences concerning policy 15 can affect the TNA strategy and can include various freedoms and constraints placed upon the Training Provider, such as: roles, tasks, structures, workforce levels, finance limits, Health and Safety 15 Particular reference should be made to the Service policies/directives for individual training requirements, minimum qualification levels for prospective role holders and/or tasks, and any accreditation or legislative issues.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: For major projects, where more than one TNA is being undertaken, it can be useful to indicate the relationship between the various TNAs.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The major types of training Methods & Media likely to be considered or examined should be included at this stage and then re-examined later.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: This will reflect the current training policy and should specify any areas requiring particular attention, such as the possible need for synthetic training, embedded training or Public/Private Partnership or Private Finance Initiative (PPP/PFI) solutions.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: These are only possible options and may change during the TOA/EA as a result of developments in policy, technology etc.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Any new training solutions may have to utilise existing training facilities and associated established support elements (ie course design) which should be recorded in the report.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The TNA methodology should be tailored to suit the specific training requirement but should always provide a full audit trail.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: For example, in the case of a small change to training policy, a TGA followed by a TOA to establish the most cost-effective Methods & Media would be sufficient.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Equally, if the training is to fit into an existing training activity using similar delivery techniques and Media, then a full blown TNA may be unnecessary.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The outputs from the scoping exercise and subsequent analyses should be agreed during Stage 1 of the TNA, which will allow the user to select the correct methodology and tools based on the constraints and information available at the time.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Analysis should not be conducted as a ‘check list exercise’, but should only be undertaken if it adds value to the TNA.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: An estimate of the resource allocation should be made to include the following: sources of information required including documentation and access to SMEs.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Cost of Ownership (COO) concerning the responsibility and allocation of funding across the affected budget holders for the design, installation, operation and supportability of the recommended training solution.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The RA is the process of examining a specific Role in detail, in order to identify all the component duties and tasks, the Conditions under which the Role is performed, and the Standards to be achieved when performing the Role.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: 16Task is a major component of a Role or duty that can be produced, compiled, achieved and/or accomplished by itself.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Therefore, it can be argued that jobs (in the traditional sense of a person conducting a single task requiring a single skill, for example) seldom exist.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: An example would be a RN Catering Services rating, who is trained in the primary Role but routinely has other Roles and duties aboard ship that are not related to the primary role (such as firefighting and First Aid).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Training that person for the job of Catering Services/Fire Fighter/First Aider is impractical, but training that person for the primary Role , then the Role of fire fighter and the First Aider makes more sense.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Identification of Role There is a danger of concentrating wholly on the Role and so there is a requirement to widen the perspective to consider it in context.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: This context may affect not only the way the RA is conducted but also the eventual design of the training solution.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: As part of the identification process, users may wish to produce a Role Specification 18 and/or Role Description within the context of the individual Role, taking into consideration the factors listed below.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Written in the same format, these either amplify the main objective by showing what must be done to achieve it or indicate additional areas of Performance within the Role.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Duties are the principal activities of the Role holder, are directly related to the Role and are subordinate to the overall Role objectives.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: An exhaustive list of every trivial condition is not necessary and only the important Conditions should 18 TAFMIS has forms entitled ‘Role Specification’ and ‘Role Description’ to assist with this process.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: It would also be convenient to include under ‘responsibilities’ information to the degree of supervision exercised over the Role holder and the extent to which they would be held accountable for their own work or the work of others.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: It will be useful to consider both positive and negative influences on skill fade so that the impact of changes to the design of the Role (e.g.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: This information, along with the KSA, Difficulty, Importance, Frequency (DIF) and criticality analyses will help to inform the identification of appropriate training Methods & Media for both the acquisition and refreshment of Role-related skills and knowledge.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: A Role Scalar is produced by analysing the duties, tasks, sub-tasks and task-elements (Performance) that have to be performed and recording them diagrammatically.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The Production of the Role Scalar is a key part of the RA process as it defines the minimum Performance to be achieved in the Defence environment.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: It is important to employ a hierarchical numbering system within a Role Scalar, as often it is cross-referenced to other training documentation.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Figure 3: Role Scalar Numbering System Role Scalars are particularly useful tools for: displaying a structure to the Role that may not be apparent in real life.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: showing tasks to be performed with new equipment, related to existing Roles, and thus help assess the impact of new equipment.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Role Scalars also have disadvantages that should be considered: they do not contain Standards and Conditions and appear to give all tasks an equal importance.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: An important consideration in developing the structure of a Role is the aim to describe what the Role holder does, or should be capable of doing, and not what they need to know.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Role Scalars cannot in themselves be used to design training and should be supported by a full Role PS and/or Framework(s).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: However, they are a vital step in the production of required outputs such as a Role PS, Framework(s) and TOs.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: DIF Analysis DIF Analysis is a method of analysing Role information through the Difficulty, Importance and Frequency (DIF) of tasks and sub-tasks, with the aim of enabling early training decisions, such as the generation of Initial Training Categories20.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The DIF Analysis assesses the difficulty, importance and frequency of tasks using a simple algorithm, which is shown in Table 1.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: As DIF Analysis relies on subjective data it is essential that each level is clearly defined to try and increase the reliability of the data.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Suggested definitions used within the DIF Analysis are as follows: Difficulty assesses the chance of performance error by asking the question: “What is the possibility of inadequate performance from the average job holder?” The range can be defined by using two extreme statements, namely, ‘The task is easily performed once learnt’ to, ‘The task requires constant practice and supervision’.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Importance, assumes that performance error is made and assesses the impact of the error by asking the following question: “What is the impact/consequence to operational capability, safety, lost revenue and public relations if the task is performed inadequately?” Once again the range can be defined by using two extreme statements, for example, ‘Failure is unlikely to have any impact upon operational capability or well being of personnel or equipment’ to ‘Failure will have an immediate and severe impact upon operational capability or risk of severe injury or damage to equipment’.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Frequent tasks may or may not be Important or Difficult and scales may range from ‘Once or more a day’ to ‘Once a year’ to ‘Never’ (if the task has changed then the requirement to carry out specific sub-tasks may have reduced to nothing).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Task frequency becomes significant, however, when considering retraining, since frequently performed tasks do not require retraining if performance is adequate.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The following factors may be included during analysis to collect information for future use: Relative time spent on the task (very much above average, above average, below, average, average, very much below average).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: An assessment of difficulty encountered in carrying out each task, the importance of each task to the achievement of the main job objective and the frequency with which tasks are performed, are key factors in making training decisions and priorities.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: DIF analysis is a useful technique which contributes to providing a rational basis for making decisions on the design of training which is superior to guesswork or intuition.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: However, other criteria may be used to decide upon levels of training; including numbers of service personnel performing the task, ease of training within the unit, how soon after training someone is expected to perform the task and how much time is spent performing the task.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Knowledge, Skills and Attitude Analysis A KSA Analysis is a systematic analysis of ‘Performance’ and/or ‘Standards’ in order to identify the necessary KSA required to perform a Role.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: A KSA Analysis moves on from what the Role holder does (captured in the Role Scalar), to identifying the KSA that have to be learned to perform the task.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The results of an Initial KSA Analysis will help with the generation of Training Objectives and Enabling Objectives and the selection of the most appropriate training Methods & Media, during Element 2 (Design).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: When carrying out a task, a possible pre-requisite is knowledge of: When to perform; what are appropriate tactics, techniques, procedures, tools or materials? Where are the tactics, techniques, procedures, components, materials and/or equipment? How to use/operate the tactics, techniques, procedures, materials, tools and/or equipment? What are the safety procedures or constraints; what possible dangers are there? What are the testing or checking requirements and procedures involved? What constitutes task completion? It is important to note that a Role PS can refer directly to a requirement for knowledge when it is linked to the practical performance in a Role as stated in the Role PS.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: For example, where key references are available at the time a task is performed, there may only be a requirement to learn how to access the information rather than learn the contents.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: It would not be possible for the trainee to learn all of these things as facts because too many individual instances exist.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: These skills are learned in connection with common activities such as using a computer, driving a car or playing a musical instrument.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Complex physical skills can often be broken down into smaller sub-skills, which can be learned separately and then put together for total performance.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: An example of this is swimming, which has 3 sub-skills (arm action, leg action and breathing technique), which can be learned and practised separately and then performed as one.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: More complex skills such as flying/driving, are similarly broken down into their component parts and taught as discrete skills in discrete lessons.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The identification of Standards relating to personal qualities and Attitudes is perhaps the most challenging part of the KSA Analysis.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Attitude is defined as a predisposition resulting in a tendency to act or react in a certain manner when confronted with another person, group, object, situation or idea.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: It is important to understand that this predisposition to think and feel in a certain way does not necessarily result in observable behaviours.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: However, this attitude may not be obvious to others when the individual is handling a dog with which they are familiar and have learned is friendly.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: A lecture on computer security may be successful in imparting information on how viruses are transmitted but unless it develops an attitude of security consciousness the trainees may not use the knowledge they have gained on the subject.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: A Behaviourally Anchored Rating Scale (BARS) is an example of a tool which can be used to assess observable behaviour objectively.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Although a BARS (Table 3) can be used to measure attitude indirectly through observing behaviour, much care is needed when inferring Attitudes from observable behaviours alone.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Note that whilst BARS is predominantly a tool used in the training environment, forming part of the ASpec if appropriate, it is mentioned here because it is useful to bear it in mind at the RA stage.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: COMMUNICATION Table 3: Behaviourally Anchored Rating Scale Although Attitudes may be inferred from observable behaviours this is prone to biases (e.g.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: This might infer that they do not care (Attitude) about 21 Defence uses a Continuous Attitude Survey which measure and captures Attitudes towards many aspects of military life.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: In order to develop an optimised training system it is important to consider both how Knowledge, Skills and Attitudes are acquired and how they are retained over time.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Understanding the rate at which different types of Knowledge and Skills fade can inform training design and the setting of refresher training intervals.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: In order to conduct refresher training interval analysis, it can be useful to use a more detailed breakdown of Knowledge and Skills than that discussed in DSAT activity – Initial Knowledge, Skills, Attitudes (KSA) Analysis.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Literature from psychology and cognitive science suggests that Knowledge and Skills can be broken down as shown in Table 4.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Table 4: Knowledge and Skills Domains Without practice, continuous psychomotor skills and explicit knowledge are retained for the longest; discrete psychomotor and decision-making skills have moderate retention over time and procedural skills fade the most quickly.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The retention of Knowledge and Skills over time is moderated or influenced by how often the task is performed or practised.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Table 5 shows the impact of task performance frequency on the retention of the different types of Knowledge and Skills.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Table 5: Effect of Task Frequency on Knowledge/Skill Retention The retention level of the Knowledge and Skills for a given task should be taken into account when setting refresher training intervals.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: It is important to note that a number of role-related factors (in addition to frequency of task performance) can also influence Knowledge and Skill fade, e.g.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: designing equipment, job aids and operating procedures in accordance with good practice (which includes built-in user feedback for equipment and interfaces, logical steps within procedures).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Training methods, media and assessment regimes which ensure the effective acquisition of knowledge and skills in the first place also help to reduce skill fade.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Table 6: Training Strategies to Improve Retention of Knowledge and Skills Initial Training Categorisation A thoroughly conducted RA will be wide ranging and will include consideration of levels of supervision, work conditions, task criticality, difficulties and distastes, frequency of task performance, Role-related skill fade factors, percentage of personnel performing the Role and consequences of inadequate performance.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: All of this information, in conjunction with information on trainee entry standards, trainee throughput and knowledge of the likely training environment, can lead to conclusions regarding the balance between training delivered as part of the TPS and training delivered as part of the WTS.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: A number of techniques may be used to derive training categories, with the main analytical tool being the DIF Analysis already conducted.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Once a suggested training category has been selected (using information from the DIF Analysis), it should be subject to further review as other factors may result in an increase or decrease in category.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Other criteria that may influence the training categories that relate to the Role environment are listed below: How many people perform the task? This may determine the need for training and the priority given.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Tasks falling into this category, and how they are dealt with, are covered in the next section (Element 2, Design, 2.2.3, RTGS).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: If closely supervised when performing a task, the training category may be reduced since the supervisor can detect errors in- role and then correct them.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The training Standards may deliberately be higher than the required Defence standard in terms of timing or accuracy to avoid knowledge/skill fade.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Regardless of training category, a task may have to be included in training if those trained are to be authorised to carry out the task.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The inclusion of training for a task originally allocated a low category may be critical for obtaining legally mandated civilian accreditation, which is a mandated requirement of that Role.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Role Performance Statement A Role PS is produced and maintained by the TRA and is a detailed statement of the tasks, sub-tasks and so forth that are required to be undertaken by an individual to achieve the articulated workplace Performance.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: It includes the Conditions under which the tasks will be undertaken, the Standards that must be achieved, and adds an indication of the importance of the training required to achieve the task Performance.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Whilst a single Role PS can be produced to cover all the duties associated with a Role, a Role PS may alternatively be written for a specific duty where it is shared across many Roles (such as the duty of firefighting).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Identify and list the important Conditions under which the tasks will be performed (an exhaustive list of every trivial condition is not necessary).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The Conditions statements should specify the physical location, level of supervision and any other particular environmental factors associated with the task.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: It may be important that certain procedures are followed in a particular sequence in order to successfully achieve the Performance.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: If not, these steps may be given as process Standards and are the essential sub-tasks and task-elements from the HRA.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Where Standards are defined in more detail in other documents, the references should be in full and include the issue number and date.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: As covered in training categorisation (Section 3.3), this states the training level required to achieve the task Performance and the balance between training to be managed and/or delivered by the TDA (e.g.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The user may wish, as a result of the RA (particularly the KSA Analysis), to consider the production of either a competence framework or competency framework, or both; either in addition to, or instead of, a Role PS.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: It is, however, important to understand both the people and training aspects, as different methodologies of analysis fit different needs, and, within the Defence context, they are sometimes confused.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The relationship between competency, competence and performance needs to be understood in a consistent manner: Competency (plural: competencies) is the underlying characteristic(s) of an individual which results in effective and/or superior performance within a Role.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Professional competency frameworks can also be used in order to provide guidance to defined professional groups, such as the Royal Navy’s Command Competency Framework, where there is a need for longer term individual professional development and/or selection.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Competence (plural: competences) is the measured ability of an individual to consistently perform a particular occupational skill or range of skills to a required Standard, under prescribed Conditions.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The Role PS serves as the statement of the 23 In this instance, however, analysts must ensure that their references are up to date.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The essential distinction is between aspects of the role at which the individual is competent (the competence), and aspects of the individual that enable them to be competent (the competency).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Figure 4: Relationships between Competency, Competence and Performance Figure 5 illustrates that both competency and competence are essential enablers of individual performance; they are not mutually exclusive.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Therefore, effective human capability development should not neglect either; instead, consideration of both will result in optimal requirement setting and solution development.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Competence development (in the form of a Role PS and associated training solutions) is covered under the DSAT training analysis process contained within this policy.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Furthermore, DSAT derived training solutions may either require some competencies as a pre-requisite or be developed during a training solution (often at the EO level).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Competence Frameworks Competence frameworks are not the sole preserve of Defence and many external bodies and organisations utilise and develop them.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Where an external awarding body has already developed an appropriate competence framework (usually in the form of job-related standards/qualifications grouped under competence areas) it is acceptable within the DSAT process to utilise this, as appropriate, rather than developing bespoke a Role PS from scratch.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: This has the added benefit of easing the accreditation process and aiding skills transfer from both within Defence and externally (particularly during transition to civilian life).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The use of an established competence framework does not absolve the analyst from capturing both the requirement and solution within the TrAD along with the necessary documentation; ensuring it is endorsed by the CEB.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: In particular, where a competence framework is used, CEBs should assure themselves that the solution does not greatly exceed the requirements of the role just in order to meet desirable external accreditation or to save resource expenditure on the analysis phase, which may be detrimental to the final training solution.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Competency Frameworks Similarly, competency frameworks are also used outside of Defence as they are recognised to have applications across a whole range of developmental activities, including training.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Competency frameworks are now seen as an essential vehicle for achieving organisational performance through the development of ‘human capital’ by reviewing individual capability and potential.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Essentially, competency frameworks are a human resource tool and are generally used at organisational or functional level and can be used in selection, performance development and training.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Competency frameworks are used to document required organisational behaviours, under grouped competency areas; such as Leadership, Communication, Problem-solving and Team-working.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Where competency frameworks exist, it is acceptable to use them within DSAT, if the behavioural descriptors are appropriate within the context of Defence.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Competence Retention Analysis (CRA) is a scientific methodology developed as a practical approach to predicting the retention of different knowledge and skills that underpin military tasks at the workforce level.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: It is relevant to two audiences as follows: Training analysts can use the outputs of CRA during the Training Needs Analysis (TNA) process to justify training solutions and the training budget; and Training designers can use the outputs of CRA during the design phase to inform the scheduling of refresher training or practice intervals, and during the development of training to mitigate knowledge and skills fade.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: CRA can also be used retrospectively to improve training design and to inform decision making about the specification of training priorities (initial and refresher), where issues are identified during the TNA evaluation process.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Link: Training Gap Analysis Introduction The purpose of the TGA is to identify the additional training requirement of the affected Role holders by determining the training gap between the Performance as stated in the Role PS / Framework(s), and any existing training Performance Standard(s).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: This analysis also enables the impact upon Defence capability to be assessed if the new or changed Defence capability is implemented without additional training.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: the additional learning requirements, if any, of the Role holders in terms of KSA at the sub-task and task-element levels.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: statements of Training Gaps24, in terms of any Performance delta, between the requirements of the Role PS / Framework(s) and any existing TOs.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The decision whether to provide additional training or not, by providing a summary of the implications of the new Performance requirements when compared to existing training.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: This should be presented as statements for each task, identifying additional workplace and unit training requirements with a statement of any associated penalties regarding reduction in capability.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: If the option to continue existing training with existing resources is an acceptable risk for all Role PS identified in the RA, then the TNA is complete and a TOA may not be required.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Whilst the TNA is designed to look at the gap that cannot be delivered by existing training, it should also consider the resource implications on existing training activities and the ability of those Training Providers to deliver in respect of a change in training throughput.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: For example, there will be two gaps if some personnel are migrating from a predecessor system to a new system, while others are coming directly from basic training to the new system.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Statement of Training Gaps These are statements in terms of the Performance delta between the requirements of the Role PS / Framework(s) and any existing TOs and EOs, including associated specialist qualifications, for each affected Role holder.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: They help ensure that the associated trainers, support staff and trainees have a clear understanding of what the trainees are required to learn and to be able to do at the end of the lesson/learning event.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: TOs form the basis of the detailed design of each of the training lessons as well as identification of appropriate training resources.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: TOs are drafted during Element 1 and then these draft TOs should be further refined and developed during Element 2 (Design).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: TOs are precise statements of what tasks a trainee should be able to do, post training, in the Role that the training was designed to prepare them for.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: A TO is measurable and has three constituents: the Performance required, the Conditions under which the trainee must perform, and the Standard to which the trainee must perform.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: These statements should be in the form of observable and measurable behaviours which allow the achievement of the TOs to be confirmed through assessment.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: A TO defines what a successful trainee is able to do at the end of a period of training, i.e.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The production of TOs may be an iterative process and should be reviewed at each stage of the design process.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The three component parts of a TO are summarised in Table 9: Table 8: Individual Training Objectives (Performance, Conditions, Standards) 25 A lesson, series of lessons, a course, exercise, or training activity.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The Performance (and sub-Performance) element of a TO states what a trainee should be able to do at the end of training and should be derived26 from the task (stated in the Role PS / Competence Framework) and therefore has an active verb as the first word in the performance element.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: When writing a TO performance for a task, the wording may need to be adjusted: if the task wording is not precise if the task has more than one objective.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The Conditions element of a TO, specifies the actual Conditions, or circumstances, in which the training Performance will take place.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Indication of location, terrain, weather, daylight, climate, the threat, psychological, physical and social factors under which the training Performance is delivered should be detailed.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Regarding the Role PS, Standards can either be product Standards (minimum absolute Standards) or process Standards (certain procedures that need to be followed in a particular sequence) or a mixture of the two.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The nature of the Performance (which could be dangerous, critical, or an emergency task), the consequence of not meeting the Standard and/or the training category should be considered.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The Standard required will ultimately affect how that Performance is 26 Derived from the task but not always a directly matching the task.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: 27 Verbs such as ‘know’ or ‘understand’ do not adequately define an action on the part of the trainee and are not observable or measurable.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: For example, if a very high Standard is required, the trainee will receive a large amount of training for the Performance (creating the possibility of becoming over-trained) and may be subject to strict assessment, such as no mistakes.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Whilst test standards should be set as closely as possible to those stated against the TO, there are certain areas where compromise may be necessary when setting test standards.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The identification of Standards relating to personal qualities, attitudes and behaviours is perhaps the most challenging part of TO development.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: TOs should be tagged to identify them as a Core (training) requirement, Legal requirement and/or Accreditation requirement, which is denoted using a letter (C, L, A) or a mark in the relevant column on the training statements with amplifying comments if appropriate.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: To ensure that training is allocated to all tasks, the link between tasks and TOs should be shown through an auditable numbering/identification system.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Table 9: Task Numbering System 28 If a performance is affected by such factors, the document or regulation should be clearly referenced in the Standards element, such as, “in accordance with publication/law/act, section X, paragraph Y, date and version.” Training Options Analysis Introduction The TOA should primarily make a recommendation as to a cost-effective training solution that meets the identified tasks or competences that require training.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Fidelity Analysis The term ‘fidelity’ denotes how closely a set of procedures were implemented as they were supposed to have been30.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Fidelity can be defined as, ‘the exact correspondence with fact or with a given quality, condition, or event; accuracy (e.g.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: the fidelity of the movie to the book or the degree to which an electronic system accurately reproduces the sound or image of its input signal’).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: This analysis should be conducted as a result of the production of a Role PS derived from the RA and include any existing Training Performance Standards.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Fidelity Analysis considers each relevant Performance objective in the Role PS to assess the extent to which the training environment should replicate the workplace (real) environment to enable training to be effective.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Decisions made at this stage can have a significant impact on the nature and cost of training solutions, as fidelity can be a significant cost driver, so it is important not to ‘gold plate’ the fidelity requirements, but instead determine the appropriate level of fidelity that is essential to achieve the desired training effect.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: The results of Fidelity Analysis will help inform the Conditions under which training should be conducted to adequately prepare trainees for their future Roles.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Fidelity can be divided into four categories and sub-categories, combinations of which may apply to each Role PS task / Competence / Competency being analysed.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: 30 For example, if the Role conducted in the workplace environment (the real world) must be done at 100%, and the training environment can only replicate the workplace environment to 89%, then that is the fidelity to which the training requirement matches the role requirement.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: It is not to be confused with Gap Analysis, as fidelity is about replicating the totality of the real environment in training, rather than seeking the gap between existing training and new/changed training requirements.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Physical fidelity can be useful to familiarise trainees with the visual, spatial and tactile characteristics of equipment, consoles, compartments, platforms and threats (including applicable reference manuals, Standing and Emergency Operating Procedures etc).

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Functional fidelity is useful in providing trainees with exposure to equipment functionality, doctrinal procedures, and maintenance routines which are required to be exploited in order to deliver the desired military effect.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Environmental fidelity can be useful in preparing or ‘acclimatising’ trainees for the conditions they will be operating under and simulating some of the conditions that can hinder Performance.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: It can be easy to ‘gold plate’ environmental fidelity requirements beyond what is essential to provide the necessary cues, stimuli and responses, but high levels of environmental fidelity can be beneficial in exposing trainees to complex operating environments and ‘fog of war’ type issues.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Tactical and cultural fidelity will help identify requirements that enable individuals and teams to train as they intend to operate.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Exposing trainees to the types of units, threats, allies (including neutral or ‘white’ forces), cultural issues and geographical locations that they will experience on operations, can also be used for mission rehearsal training or tactical development.

document: DTSM 2 Analysis of Individual Training 2023 Edition V1.0.docx
content: Tactical and cultural fidelity can be broken down into these sub-categories: 31 To succeed on many operations, UK Armed Forces will need to understand and interpret the nuances of local cultures with and within which they will be operating.
